body: ... (oh, crap...a spontaneous essay. *Some* things never change...sigh.)footnote first:**...** = I know what you'll think of, but that is not metaphorical. There are no metaphors employed herein, not by me, nor are there any attempts at doublespeak, casual code, or other efforts to pretend I'm saying something I'm not. That's not my department..............................Before I go:Why did you(s) come looking/calling out for me, in particular, after (throughout?) so many years?Moreover, why do you(s?) want me to 'know' so much (insofar as I can suss it out, anyway... which can't be impressing you(s) all that much, I'm sure)?Did I harm you(s) in some way? I don't like causing harm to people (or anything else, for that matter) so I hope not. If I did, that merits (real, face to face) discussion (to paraphrase myself ;-) ). If that's what is needed, please inquire.I'm hoping for genuine, sincere, human answers to these questions, but certainly not counting on them.I wish you(s) well... I wish everyone - all of us, everwhere in this wacky, troubled world - well. Maybe someday you'll come to feel the same way; maybe not...and if you(s) can't or won't get there, I'm sad for that. Smart as you(s) be, the world is missing out on the awesome force for good you(s) could be.(tl;dr, as the kids say - take a no-doz now or close the window; here comes the navel-gazing and pontificating)As for the paradoxical nature of 'love' vs. 'in love' (not that I think anyone was asking Me, necessarily; the reference just made me think about it):When, for whatever reason, a person realizes they're at odds with/unsure of their self-concept, they may also realize that 'in love' is not a reliable state of mind, much as one might believe they feel it. When a person comes to terms with the fact that they don't/haven't/no longer know their 'self' very well, they may see that it's hard to know anyone else well, thus 'in love' isn't a feeling you can interpret with any accuracy while in that state.So:  When I was in that place, back-then - **self-aware but without self-mastery** - I felt...no, I *decided* - even though I didn't necessarily want to...that just loving, in the purest sense I could manage while consciously setting aside the implicit needfulness of 'in love', was the most fair and right thing for both of us/everyone.I could not control my feelings of love, but I could control *how* to feel them, their **execution**, if you will.In short:  If I could not bring my best self (to you) , I should not go, nor ask anyone (you) to go with me/ask me to come...and at that time, I couldn't...so I didn't. I really did wish I could, though, at the time - more than almost anything - but it wouldn't have been right or healthy, even if you had wanted it, which I heard you to say you did not, and believed you to be truthful.It was three more years before I believed I had enough personal, inward clarity - and enough confidence in my ability to  be outwardly clear-eyed -  to allow myself to approach/be approached by someone for an intimate relationship. It has worked out well, with few bumps, relatively speaking, and I'm happy with the outcome. I love him very much, and he loves me, and we accept each other, flaws and all. In-love waxes and wanes, love stays steady, it's wonderfully quiet and peacefully dull (usually...grrrr!!!).That's the short view of my personal experience, anyway, with the differences and the overlappings. Can't speak for anyone else.That place on the hill, where we went the night we met? It was torn down years ago, replaced by some chain behemoth. I will always remember it, though, and smile whenever I drive past what once-was-but-could-never-be.

body: I knew it when I saw your tattoo, so I started a conversation on the subject. I told you I play a couple of instruments, but didn't mention that I love music too. That fact alone could have been the basis for a great friendship, but your being a girl, and me being a stranger guy attempting to 'break the ice,' precipitated the classical statement 'I have a boyfriend, I don't think it would be appropriate.' And I kept wondering all day, why is it that guys can have plenty of girlfriends, but it is not 'appropriate' for women to make new male acquaintances when they have a significant other? This could pass as just another typical situation in which a woman turns down a guy that is trying to 'hit on her,' if it weren't for I was genuinely attempting to relate to another soul on the basis of a mutual passion for music, and I believed that you were truly convinced of what you were telling me. Friendship does not have to involve the sexual element, but somehow we have been programmed to believe that such bond between a woman and a man cannot exist. Prejudice got in the way. This was truly a missed connection.
title: You Told Me You Love Music - missed connections

body: So here's the short story version of the chance encounter that this city is made for:Man 2 man, we met at that coffee shop on East 6th near 1st ave.  Yeah. Too bad you couldn't make it over then for more talk and that deep tissue rub down, a happy much needed release of yer stress and duress.  Hope your exams and oral reports went well.  So, remember, I'm not too far from you in East Village near St. Marks Church.  If your schedule's free now or soon then come on over and I'll give you an easy exam, oral only, no paper or cyber w/grades and such, only inquistive, probing and learning from the inquiries, and you'll report, give feedback, a learning experience for us both, man to man, older-younger, a great combo for such.  Very Greek, ancient, pre-Socratic, the dialectical procedure of evocation via inquiry and patient demonstration.  Hands on learning.  Experiential.  Best way to learn. I recall you're Asian - Korean perhaps? 3rd culture? didn't ask, doesn't matter, whatever, very nice looks, and masculine, good shape...hard to tell what age you are, what, 18 to 28? anyway, you're med study intensities then needed (still need) some hands on contact.  That's pretty much it.  Just in case you forgot, I'm the older man with the psychology books, the ones on dreams and their interpretation  - you shared a few dreams, the one with the airborn wheelbarrow and the fox, wow, much to say about that one - stacked high on the table lol, almond croissant crumbs on said books, table top, my lap,  powdered sugar on my chin and black shirt, yikes, thanx for pointing that out! lol.  Oy! First impressions!!!  You sat at the table next to me at Elsewhere and asked about the books, what I do - teach, write, consult/counsel, also massage and energy work so I too can change channels out of my head and into more physical relating to life, self, others, etc.  You said your brain was 'maxed out', you were extremely anxious and hadn't slept but a few hours a night for weeks and that your 'body needed to come alive.' After some rest and relaxation, some natural easy release of all that stress, your nervous system is maxed out, neurochemicals of cortisol storms depleted your adrenals, glands, and the subjective experience of who you are as a body whose ego is afflicted with academic demands for high achievement. Jeez.  I'm exhausted just describing you to yourself!  So.  'Yeah.  I'm perfect for that,' I said.  You grinned wide.  'Deal?' 'Deal!'  High fives and a wink wink to seal it.  And I bought your macha and your gluten free cookie for you.  What's a gentleman to do after all, the surprise of a friendly meeting, great conversation and sharing, laughing (as quietly as possible in that tiny espresso joint, tables close beside each other).  Yes, I do look younger for my age,  wear it, age, well, I work out at a gym not too far from you.  I'm toned.  Said I wasn't into that body building stuff...just tone, keep it together, get some cardio since I sit alot, am stationary too much because a lot of my work is studying, reading, writing so, yeah, I need to move it and shake loose.  About me, we didn't get into this when we met, Spanish mixed background, mom Cherokee Indian and Irish mix, dad Canary Islander (Spain), Latino, stray gringo in there too, southern Louisiana swamp dna mix, I guess, beast of the southern wild meets my dinner with Andre (an ancient movie, check it out), ...my green eyes come from mom tho.  She and dad grayed early.  Both wore it well as do I.  Laughter is indeed the best medicine and regular body contact and frequent rest.  Getting some of whatever off the chest too.  Soft belly breaths and deep sighs, hands soft on sky parts skin and and rough patches too to undo daily grind in exchange for bump kind, grind that is.  Skies and sighs the limit.  And deep let go.  Hasten slowly, said one of my best teachers in massage and trance work.  Yes.  That.  Exactly.  So if by chance you see this get in touch.  Summer's here.  I have time on my hands too and so can get my hands to work on you if yer up for it, all of it, handfuls of ahhhhhh soooooooooo.....and steady as he goes.  You'll be in control at all times.  I do only what you are comfortable with, respect boundaries.  You said you are shy so I want to remind you what I said about discretion and boundaries and that 'you da boss' - you call the shots, I swallow them or something like that lol.  We can go into all that and more when you contact me.And, yes, I will read you some Walt Whitman, the Calamus poems, a few of his entries from Specimen  Days, those tender civil war accounts of his sweet presence with the wounded soldiers, north and south, white and black...but that's enough.  And after the body work and rest/relax/deep snooze.Am up late too. Summer hours for lingering.  Soon then, I hope.
title: UrTheStr8AznDudeNearNYU-UneededMassageNMoreButUhad2study - missed connections

body: Responding to a prior post ---100% correct. Disregarding what your brain and gut tell you in favor of what your emotions prefer can be seen as a 'connection issue'. A deep desire to look for the good in people, and encourage that goodness to surface, a conviction that your faith and trust in them will ultimately bejustified, a willingness to make excuses for poor behavior and forgive and renew is a problem and a connection issue.  One who suffers this does have to be re-programed. Trusting, loving and sharing the generosity of your spirit are gifts to be given wisely.  Even with time, too many people who enter your life will prove undeserving. Those of us who were raised to love, understand and forgive are at a disadvantage when dealing with too many others whose roots were either not nourished  or whose heart and soul  were corrupted over a lifetime of disappointments and negativity.  Yes it's painful to acknowledge a person you appreciated, cared sincerely about and hoped to have a lasting place in your life--regardless of the nature of the relationship, was truly unworthy.  Sometimes the other person's issues overridethe goodness you choose to see in them. Will be working on this challenging issue!
title: CONNECTION ISSUE  FOR SURE - missed connections

body: Last night (9/8/2018), I was stopped at a red light on Morehead.  You were to my right in an SUV. The light turned red for the cars passing in front of us on Roxboro.  The light turned green for us.  You accelerated slightly, and I could see the light from the headlight of an oncoming vehicle through the windows of your SUV.  I assumed the vehicle that was approaching us would stop, so I started to accelerate. However, you stopped about a second after accelerating through the green light.  I followed your cue, though I did go about a foot past your vehicle.  The massive white pickup truck zoomed past us, a foot or two in front of us.  We both almost got T-boned.  I probably would have accelerated through the green light if you hadn't stopped, and I would have been T-boned and if not dead, then severely injured.  After the truck passed in front of us, you must have been in shock, because you didn't move your SUV for at least 20 seconds (I checked my rear-view).  I looked to my right to ensure no more cars were going through their red light on Roxboro.  I accelerated forward on Morehead and merged onto NC-147, grateful that you braked at the green light.Thank you for paying attention to the road.  Considering the most likely of possible outcomes: You saved my life. - TA
title: You Saved My Life at Morehead & Roxboro - missed connections

body: Do you remember the night when we went to the movies - how our mutual friend sat between us and you gave me your scarf to keep me company?I do. It's been seventeen years since we last spoke and I'm still haunted by the mystery of our ending. Sometimes, when sleep is slow to come, I think about you and try to figure out what happened. I try and remember the smallest of details looking for a clue to help me understand. I vividly remember the night you told me how you no longer wanted my affection. I did my best with my head down, my headphones on and the music cranked up to 10. I tried to be professional. I fought the good fight to tamp down my emotions and ignore the feelings of despair and jealousy when I heard you laughing with our co-workers. Slowly but surely I was detaching; then you said you wanted to speak with me. I resisted, then acquiesced. If we had meet anywhere else but that restaurant, if he had sat someplace more private; maybe I would have been able to answer your question. Maybe I wouldn't have been so tongue-tied... we could have remained friends. I could not explain that night, but I think I can now. Hindsight is a wonderful thing. It gives perspective and illuminates our failings. My hope is that you will let me explain, that you will let me tell you what I could not that night. And I hope you accept my apology. I'm not looking for a second chance. Life has carried us both past that now. I merely want to set the record straight and to understand.If you are willing then please respond to this post and we will go from there.
title: AKA 'Marzsipan' - missed connections

body: This is an outrageously absurd shot in the dark that I'm penning out for the amusement of all 'missed connections' binge readers. And my first missed connection at that! Eeek, commence the awkward narrative writing:I got on at the Ralph Avenue train stop at around 8:47am this morning-it was the Manhattan bound C train. I'm not sure if you were on when I boarded but after the Utica Avenue station I moved from the door to stand in the middle and that's where you were. You didn't notice me at first but then idk through the corner of my eye it seemed that you looked at me for a long gander. (I should also mention to all binge readers that this experience is primarily based on side eye observations and the absence of my morning coffee-so I could very well be insane.) you and I took turns looking at each other with peripheral efforts and window reflections, though I'm not sure if you noticed. You're a mid-late 20s white male. Dirty blonde/light brown hair that you kept playing with suddenly in the window reflection...peacocking? You have some beard scruff going. To be honest there are some details that are a little fuzzy as I was too nervous to look at you for long in the event you would have caught me and the train would have stopped as it usually does. Yea...that would have been awkward. But you were wearing an oversized jacket...I think dark grey, jeans, and a tie dye blue shirt. On your left you were carrying a tote bag and I think you had a metal necklace as well. I was wearing all black. Black leggings, jacket, boots. I think you kept looking at my boots to see how high the heel was to see if I was taller than you lol I mean, I was in that moment but it was all heels. My dark hair was in a pony tail  with the exception of a stubborn bang gone awry. I'm 5'6 fair skinned 27 year old woman; I was wearing dark lipstick and painted dark nails.  A thicker frame. I was also carrying a bulky tote that said the name of a college campus which I can specify later, and cupping a travel mug. You may have tried to been figuring out if I was a student; I'm not. I moved into the middle of the cart further to stand next to you hoping you would say something to me. It seemed like you started to fidget more as did I. Then again you could have felt suffocated and this is all in my head lol I wish I could say that's not a plausible option for me. I really wanted to see your eye color and hoped you would accidentally bump into me so I stepped closer which you noticed. I told myself it's such a guy thing to bump into a girl to strike a conversation and hoped you would do it. And you did! I think your eyes are blueish, maybe Aqua. Mine are hazel. You said sorry about that and then I nervously tried to smile and mumble you're fine. I guess I'm bad at this. I ended up getting off at Hoyt-Sch. to transfer. ANYWHO, if this sounds like you and you found my awkward narrative endearing I'd like to hear from you, even if at minimum to confirm I'm not entirely delusional. P.S, I liked you-in case that wasn't already obvious.
title: Manhattan Bound C Train This Morning-F4M - missed connections

body: You were working at Jill's that evening. The first time we talked, I asked you to marry me. Crazy yes, but you were 'that girl'. You were blonde, 27 or 28, about 5'8' and the most beautiful woman I had ever laid my eyes on. You carried a few extra pounds and you looked like a goddess, albeit the girl next door. We talked all night around your work. You had just moved back to Pittsburgh from New York where you had been living with a guy who won a lottery. But when the money was gone, he broke up with you even though you loved him, not his money. You got a job at the courthouse in the Burgh and you had just started working at Jill's and trying to get back on your feet. We had a great connection and eventually we were talking like old friends. Nothing could have been better! We spent quality time together that night and you suggested making plans after your work was finished. But you got occupied and I got sleepy....and I went back to my truck to sleep. Oh...your friend wanted you to join her at a club in town to see the band Marcy Playground, but you had no idea who they were. I absolutely was so smitten by you....and scared of our strong attraction at the same time....I was not in a great emotional place at that time...and I never stopped by to find you again. I know I would never have left! My work has me passing by Jill's twice a day now....and I often wonder about the woman that I let get away. I don't remember your name and surely you do not remember mine, but I cannot forget the many details of that night that you stole my heart. Nor the regret of never having the chance to say good night to you. I have never entered that establishment since that night.  'Through the too many miles and the too little smiles, I still remember you'I know that there is a very slim chance this posting gets results but there would be no chance if I did not write this. So if anyone has any idea who this lady is, I would surely love to know. Actually I will pay a finder's fee! I do not intend to cause any problems for this lady....I just want to know how her life turned out without me. I know that sounds cheesy, but maybe you can understand where I am coming from. Thank you for reading this. Hope your life is ok also.Russ in Maryland

Other girls flocked to you like toxic honey.Everyone thought we were a joke being a couple. It wasn't to me. That divided me from them. They destroyed our innocence. Again I tried left and right. What you do ? Nothing.I went off the deep end of coma because therapy wasn't helping and the moon shined through my windows saying just leave.Then I realized I was in love with you but you weren't in love with me.I left out of state.Another decade passed, what you do ? Wreck havoc on me and blamed me for everything like you gave a cow's sh*t.Stop right there, you had no business to do that, twisting all of that like it wasn't your fault.First off, I don't know what happened to you in between decades. You never wrote to me, never called me, never made any effort to see me. I got tired of having to make the effort every single time. body: I was riding through....a firm but still laid back kinda loose hold on my Honda Fit's steering wheel...I'm about out of gas but not quite...it was a chilly day, but not like, so chilly that it mattered how chilly...the shoppers bustled around the Wal Mart Parking Lot.... I almost hit a few, 'sorry!' I called out to a woman and her newborn baby. 'You fu^%#g a**hole!!' She called back...oh well, I thought... Another dreary day, and I needed to get to the bank behind the old WalMart Super Center (I'm pretty sure that it's just recording faces for FEMA camps and you seem like you'd know absolutely nothing about that conspiracy theory...u seem so innocent).... I cross slowly over the speed bump, I spot you, at first glance I think you are an angel. At second glance... I think you are: Amy. I yell, 'AMY!!' My voice cracking. I wave. You look absolutely terrified, and genuinely confused ... rightfully so. You slowly raise your right hand and wave, weakly, back, unsure...with a look like 'I'm nice but seriously who the #*%k is that?' Because you don't know anyone who drives a silver Honda Fit. I don't either. Except, I do. My gesture slowly changes from a friendly wave as a tall middle finger rises, conquering the wind... your look stays the same... your hand lowers. It is not unlike something out of a movie... a very pointless and short movie... one that would go straight to VHS, not even DVD. Because no one would watch that movie. No one, Amy. Can I call you that? And for a moment,  the hustle and bustle of the holiday crowds is silent, the jingle of the Salvation Army bells sounds less f'ing annoying. You probably donated. I'm a monster. You are a good person. I don't deserve you....The bank was closed, Amy. My son wanted a cake pop from Starbucks because the bank was closed and he thinks the bank is just for lollipops. I belong to First Commonwealth and the one behind wal mart is my least favorite. They don't even have lollipops. Hbu? What's your bank? Email me ur hair color and bra size so I know it's probably you

body: There's a .001 in a million chance you'll ever see this. I feel crazy for even writing this post. It was Halloween 2009. We met at The Dark Room on the lower east side. You were dressed as one of the three amigos. I was Alice from Alice In Wonderland. I bet you money you'd never guess my name. We danced and you tried to kiss me. I told you I had a boyfriend and that things were rocky, but that I couldn't cheat. You gave me your number and said 'If it doesn't work out with your boyfriend, give me a call.'I spent two more years in that relationship, which I came to eventually realize was an abusive one. Memories of you, of that night, have stayed with me all these years. What if you were the out I never took? What if you were my chance to escape, and I chose not to?I get that a lot of people will say- 'hey everything happens for a reason.' Maybe we weren't met to meet again. Maybe you would have been a fling or another shitty guy who broke my heart. Maybe in the light of day, without costumes and liquor, we would have had a 'what the hell was I thinking moment.' But what if you were the choice I was supposed to make, and I made the wrong one? I guess I just need to know. I met tons of guys in NYC around this time, you're the only one who stayed in my mind. Maybe it has nothing to do with you, but with my own regrets. The romantic in me wants the cheesy rom-com ending though.
title: Halloween 2009, The Dark Room, Guy Dressed as one of The Three Amigos - missed connections

body: The screw-faced hags of Shadyside crawl out of their wolverine burrows, put on their joggers, and start screaming at cyclists who are aware that Ellsworth between North Neville and Summerlea is NOT a business district, therefore cycling on footpaths and sidewalks is not prohibited as outlined in section 3508 of PA DOT Code (Title 67) subparts 'a' and 'b'.Point and scream and gesticulate wildly at the bicycles and arrows painted on the street all you want; those are not 'bike lanes' - they are called 'sharrows'.  There is no law on the books in this state that /forces/ a cyclist to risk their life riding there outside of when in business districts or when official signage dictates otherwise.  Bike lanes will have a solid painted line (or ideally, a wall or barrier) separating them from automobile traffic.  Something for you to ponder is whether you'd be screaming at your own kid or grandkid to go ride their bike in the street with happy hour drunkards, makeup queens, iPod Sallys, Johnny Text-A-lots, and of course any one of the fine junkies who decided to get in on the big opiate abuse epidemic.  Don't forget that they all like to drive 45+ MPH in a 25 MPH zone so that they can all 'avoid traffic'. It should be quite fine for you to 'allow' cyclists to ride where they feel that their lives aren't being threatened, especially if they are following the law.  Try convincing yourself that they are human beings who are just as entitled to use the public sidewalk as you are.Thank you for your attention in this matter.Signed,Michael Patton

body: I have always been here wether you know it or not. Waiting to welcome you back. I was never angry with you. I may have been angry about the situation but I was not angry with you. I believed so strongly that fate would bring us back together.  I think I relied too much on it. Back then with the frame of mind I was in I actually thought I was doing both of us a favor by disappearing. Maybe I really did. It probably would have been difficult if we tried to get together back then. Not because of us but because of other people making it that way. It could have disrupted your life in a way that was similar to mine at that time. I think that's why you did not want to come closer. Because you knew it. I think we both knew it would be difficult. It should not have been that way. If it had been a normal situation, things may have been different. That is what I was pissed about. I felt like something that could have been great was stripped away because of foolishness. I have had other crushes and loves but I rarely think about them now. This is something that has stayed with me. It is a part of me. I always wanted to contact you but I was afraid to. I ended up waiting a long time which I should never have done. I feel like one of the worst things that could happen has happened. So much I could tell you. Don't know if you care to hear it.One of the things about getting older is that you realize what is really important even if it is late.Miss D
title: I have always been here - missed connections

body: You - a male traveler on the Economy Lot 3 shuttle at RDU International Airport. Me - a fellow traveler. I got on, placed my suitcase on the rack and sat on the right side of the bus, facing you. You quaffed your black hair with a tasteful amount of gel and wore an expensive pair of black Ray-Bans. You were tall. Your jeans, cuffed once at the ankle, fit your figure nicely. You wore a V-neck with vintage confidence. You'd recently outgrown your daily compulsion to shave your chin and lip, leaving a handsome stubble. You gripped her right hand with your left tightly. Or was it her hand that squeezed yours so tightly? On your left hand was a matte silver ring.  I can't quite place a verb for what matte jewelry does. Regular jewelry shines or gleams or glows or blings. Matte, though, absorbs light. The lack of luster is the point. Matte is anti-jewelry, an under-recognized revolt against glimmer. The grip you shared with her grew tighter. There you sat, a married man of no more than 25. Maybe a well-kept 27. Probably 23. With your wife, no younger than 34. Maybe 32. Probably 36. Her, filled out in the hips, as most women in their 30s do. Her cheeks possessing scars of a long-ago battle with acne. Brown rimmed glasses on a petite nose. A pale pink cardigan over a white tee. Her hair is auburn this week. Not actually auburn, but a color invented by L'Oreal, with a name carefully concocted to inspire impulse in a drug store shopper. The name, though, was meaningless. Since Walgreen's hair color display had 48 different products in the red-auburn spectrum, the color descriptors had the effect of blending together as much as the colors themselves. She purchased this particular L'Oreal color kit based on the rare seriousness in the model's face, which portrayed an academic gravitas that most color kit box models didn't possess. Once the color kit was applied, she felt unsatisfied about the transformation that just occurred. The color too similar to the last, the newness not quite realized. The grip grew tighter.  As she spoke you nodded. What she said I couldn't quite pick up. Snippets included a description of a girl in her junior year. A girl who was getting a lot out of a thesis project. Was she once this girl? Now she was probably 36. A library scientist at Meredith College. With her husband who was probably 23. She spoke matter-of-factly about academia's politics and hoops and red tape both students and faculty must overcome in order for goals to be achieved. Advisors, exams, credit hours per semester, resource utilization. She spoke with formality on her student and you nodded at regular intervals indicating that you understood her. You seemed to respect her. The grip grew tighter.As we passed Terminal 1, the automated message on the bus's loudspeakers indicated that Terminal 1 serves Southwest Airlines. You stayed seated. She stayed seated. I stayed seated. The grip grew tighter. Finally, you spoke. What you said I also couldn't quite pick up, though your voice was more piercing, deeper, and stronger than I had imagined. You spoke with conviction about a job at Morgan Stanley. Morgan Stanley? Was this a summer internship? A brief dalliance with a different life in New York City. A summer around people your age, picking up Sweetgreen for junior partners, absorbing the lifestyle of Wall Street. The grip grew tighter. Your voiced faded into the hum of the bus's ambience. The next line was lost in the hum. But, she replied, 'NC State', with the gentle prod of a woman's conviction. For what scenario could 'NC State' be so definite an answer? Is this your life? A series of gentle prods towards NC State? The grip grew tighter. The bus approached Terminal 2. The automated message indicated that Terminal 2 serves American, Delta, United, Spirit, Frontier, Alaska, Air France, Air Canada, and British Airways. You both stayed seated as the other riders and I got up and gathered our luggage. She turned. You two made your first eye contact of the ride. She smiled. You smiled. You leaned in and kiss her. The grip released as you stood. You grabbed her chrome luggage and your duffel and step off the bus.
title: You on the RDU Economy Lot 3 shuttle - missed connections

body: Yes, I know. Not a good start to the post. Food Lion? Clayton? It was approximately 6:30 pm on Wed. 3/6. I stopped by to pick up a few unnecessary necessities. I was standing in the checkout line, the cashier was making small talk with me and I was politely obliging. This is when she walked in. She walked with a hurried pace that is not typical amongst the Clayton Food Lion crowd. She walked right through my line of vision and right behind the cashier. Everything stopped. As my eyes followed her my head rotated like Beetlejuice, she disappeared down an aisle. The cashier became invisible and my thoughts were monopolized entirely. She had long, straight red hair. I was not fortunate enough to see her eyes but I know they're either green or blue. She wore a pink hoodie which was one size too big. She still wore it well. She wore nothing beneath it. Her leggings were patterned with what I can best describe as an American Indian print. Her womanly shape danced with her stride. How does a man explain the power of a woman and raw beauty without blurring the lines, coming across as a scumbag? I was taken. I exited the store unsure of how I would handle this situation. I stood out front for a brief moment, bags in hand arguing with myself over what to do. She had a hurried pace which meant she was on a mission, I should respect that. I'm only going to misrepresent myself if I approach her outside the store. I selflessly opted to not approach. As I drove away I saw her exit the store. I expected diapers, perhaps a box of wine to be the explanation for her pace. No.........dog food. I've regret. I only needed 10 seconds of her time to offer a smile and afford a genuine compliment. I want to look into her eyes. She needs to know how stunning she is. Please let her know.

body: Almost absurd to send a message online when you were literally sitting right next to me for most of the ride. Your eyes didn't really lift much from the screen except for a few glances toward the door to check if it was your stop. You were wearing white earbuds and moved a seat over when there was an opening by the pole. If I remember correctly, you had a messenger type bag with 'Asian American Film Festival 2012' (or something of that nature) printed in red letters. I was the girl who was also glued to her phone with wireless headphones. Writing this was an interesting exercise. Let this message go forth into the world and do something or absolutely nothing (we run by the law of excluded middle here!). If you happen by chance, come across this message -- feel free to either ignore it & have a good laugh with your friends or not. If your choice is the latter: just so I know it's you, provide some sort of description of my appearance (which is fairly unique, so that wouldn't be so hard). body: Please give this some thought...Its so sad to see so many broken hearts posting to lost loves. I read them often because it helps me find peace knowing that the pain that I feel from a lost love isn't crazy and because I hope that maybe you will say something to  me. It's a shame that lessons are learned to late and that I didn't give or take the time to heal and understand, instead horrible things were said and done. Once you lose someone you love it has a way of changing a person. I know that it has made me a better person but it doesn't change the fact that the void is still there and so many regrets are still lingering around. So to the man that I loved so much and lost due to my own stupidity and weakness with letting my anger control me, I miss you still every day and I will forever be sorry for the pain that I caused you. I hope that you've found your happiness even though I am still in search of mine. I miss your friendship the most especially right now. I'd do anything to have that back...to show you that you could trust me...I know of a way that we could be friends if you find yourself missing me too...it doesn't have to be full of hurt and pain and it wouldn't be. I promise. You know how to reach me and I will gladly explain more..please think about it... I need you and want you in my life as a friend...Update: I am surprised at how many people are feeling the same way! But this is meant for someone who has a nice butt...I always had a nickname for you because of it.
title: Lessons learned and broken hearts - missed connections

body: You come straight from work, just as I tell you to.  The hotel bar is dark, but busy.   You walked in to the Bowery, trying to act nonchalant.  Reminding yourself to look confident, un-self-aware, as if you were here for business, a conference or something, just one of the guests.  It's warm inside, thankfully, but you feel cold.  The fabric of your skirt and blouse, so thin, pressing against your skin.  You can feel the goosebumps all over your body.  The anticipation is intense, and so is the second-guessing.  Should you have come?  This is insane.  He won't show.  Your mind is racing. You sit in a comfortable chair back away from the bar.  Still trying to look nonchalant, you scan the bar anxiously, wondering if I'm there.  The businessmen at the bar, the loner here and there, wondering if one of them is me.  You order a drink from the waitress and wait.  You shouldn't have come, you tell yourself.  You drink it too quickly.  But the alcohol does its work.  You feel calmer soon.  A little more confident.  Lost in your thoughts, you only notice me casually.  I must have slipped in when you weren't looking.  But I'm there sitting at the bar, looking back at you.  When I catch your eye, our glances lock.  It feels like an eternity.  The gentle smile on my face registers -- you know that its me.  Slowly, again it seems an eternity, I lean in to the bartender, saying something to him, taking my drink and I walk back to your table.  I sit down and you smile nervously, we both smirk, giggle almost.  The awkwardness is unavoidable.  The feeling of my fingers glancing across your bare knee under the table, it sends a shiver up through your body.  Jarring at first, unexpected, but the tingle...  it lingers inside you.  You lean forward, involuntarily almost. The small talk comes with surprising effortlessness.  Work, the craziness, the weather, the other odd jobs in the hotel.  Soon it feels natural and innocent, as if we'd met with friends at lunch on a workday, without the faintest ulterior motives.  My fingers on your knee again, jars you back... to what you came for.  What you desired, but didn't know whether you had the guts to come for.  Our conversation continues, more fervently now, with witticisms back and forth, the double entendres... and all the while, my hand on your knee.  You wonder, do people see...?  Do they notice...?  My fingers, tracing out little circles now, teasingly.  Sliding around gently, so slowly, to the inside of your thigh.  Your heart races now...  you want me to stop, but you want me to continue. You think you can see the lump in my throat...  a hint of my own nervousness, breaking through amid the self-confidence that you found so alluring, so threatening.  You put your hand on mine, as if to stop me.  You decided you needed to stop me.  But you leave it there.  Your hand on top of mine, gently resting on the inside of your thigh... our fingers intertwine, as if they have a mind of their own, grasping tightly.  It's all broken, the moment, when the waitress comes again, and gives us each another drink.Curiously, now that I've moved back, let up a bit, you want it all the more.... You squirm in your seat a little, leaning forward again across the table.  You were cold before, covered in goosebumps...  you're hot now, it feels almost sweltering, you must be blushing, you tell yourself.  You feel my leg against yours now, our ankles gently glancing against each other.  You look in my eyes and I seem impossibly oblivious to how its making you writhe... right there in the bar...  until my knowing smile tells you what you hoped and wanted.  Again, my fingers... tracing out little circles... sliding upwards... so achingly slowly, up under your skirt, to the edge of your panties.  The tip of my forefinger tracing out the lines of the fabric, as you gasp just a little, doing what you can to hide it.  You grasp my hand.  I lift it up and take you from the table now.  We walk back up the the bar, as if nothing is out of the ordinary, just to settle up our bill.  You lean on the bar, trying to catch the bartender's attention, as I stand behind you, close, too close.  You feel me up against the thin fabric of your skirt...  thick, warm, bulging now... pressing up against you.  Everyone in the bar oblivious.  You lean back into me, savoring the feeling...  imagining our bodies intertwined, locked in synch. Finally I pay the bill and our hands clasp tightly, as I lead you out of the bar, to the elevator.  The elevator too is crowded, thankfully, or you wouldn't know how you could control yourself -- or what I might do if we were alone.  Again, an eternity... as we finally reach my floor.   And it begins.
title: unbearable lightness of the bowery bar - missed connections

body: I miss what we had tooBut I fear you were only “you” when it was convenient for you. You’re right. I question whether I ever knew you, because I was certain I did. But you went out of your way to show me that I didn’t. Idk what you mean by this:“It's just after I realized how much I cared for you I became a clumsy, mumbling idiot. You just make me so nervous and I'm terrified”Perhaps you can find a more meaningful way to explain what you mean.  How do you trust someone that scares you, makes you so nervous?And why do I have that affect on you? Is it my dedicated love and willingness to make you happy? Even if it means putting myself at risk, as it were? And it were, as it turned outHow can I trust someone that would destroy me on a dime and lie for the sole purpose of hurting me as deeply as possible? Anonymously, you don’t judge me. You accept me fully. Yet you named me a liar, a hypocrite.Thinking well of me must remain a secret? Publicly, you shame me for trying to make you happy, for doing what you taught me to do (as though it were my sport, you described your own behavior and pawned off all your shame onto me).But anonymously you accept me completely. What am I missing?The truth is that I’m so confused I think about you very often tooEspecially of lateI miss what you meant to me and what I thought I meant to youI think about how you were able to betray me with such easeI think about why you would?What could you have possibly gained from it? I want to forgive you every single dayI loved you like no other You were the best friend I ever hadYou know how much courage it took for me to trust you and you took that fragile yet priceless entity and shat all over it. For what reason again?You must know that I deserve a true explanation, worthy of whoever I am to you.Please help me How do we go back, when it’s so clear you’d been using me, as your toy, your distraction from boredom, your way to kill time, as you so pointedly expressed in as many ways as you possibly could? There are no words more painful, more deeply cutting, than your last ones to me. If I could forget them, I’d jump at the chance. Tell me how to forget. Or.

body: From Reed to Sue: I met you in the L train, standing by the door, Saturday night, 6/23 :). We were both traveling from BK to Manhattan, you to the West Village, me to the UES. You were magnetic, standing next to me. We struck up a conversation, you in your 'pajamas' (quotations, because you made them look like anything but pajamas), me in my blue jeans and grey t-shirt. I could hardly keep my eyes away from yours to look at the stations going by, as you teased me about my career (psychology), and told me you were studying esthiology. Me originally from KS, you from San Antonio, and not too happy with NYC. I kicked myself for not asking for your number, or Instagram, as I shook your hand, probably holding it for a bit longer than normal, because, frankly, it felt nice in mine.As for why I didn't ask: My clock is ticking, here in NYC. I leave at the end of June, and I figured you wouldn't be interested in that. But, I'm a romantic. Needless to say, this is one hell of a long shot, but I'm throwing my quarter in the fountain of missed connections. And, maybe, somehow, this'll get to you, and we'll have a 'Part II' for our conversation, and I'll be able to meet those beautiful, brown eyes of yours once more.
title: Esthiology 'Sue' from the L-Train - missed connections

body: Winter morning, a bus stop near Yonkers. You: red, frizzy hair, thick glasses, short and cute enough to fit in a pocket. Me: Tall, beard, pale with a bad buzz cut and messenger bag. Afraid of staring, so started reading A Death In Venice. You asked me if it was any good and I said “What?” even though I heard you perfectly fine. I needed a moment to swallow my own tongue and not look so interested. You leaned closer and tapped the book I was holding, which should have been a red flag, but all my mind thought was “Oh, look, freckles.” We talked Paris, German literature, angst and Renaissance art (The Early Netherlands period is your favorite.) You gushed about Bruegel and pretended to get embarrassed, which I found impressive, and you laughed when I called Werther A Whiney Little Dipass, But My Dipass none the less.We got near your stop so I wrote my number on the back of A Death In Venice and gave it to you. You didn't decline, promised to give it back, and a week later tell me that was such a suave move. Would call sometimes to what felt like brag about your encyclopedic knowledge of art history. A smart mind might be exciting but when a person has a passion, I think God shines through them. Other times you felt like practicing with your tarot cards and read my future, and to this day the seven of swords is always in my head and heart.   We drifted come Spring, which is fine. I’ve had my own things happening, and I know moving has not been easy on you. The best is the most any of us can ever do, and distance means growth, even its in opposite directions. It was nice we crossed branches for a while and that I got to know you. I’m grateful for the few nights and smiles we shared, and hope you find your magpie very far from the gallows.But also, and most importantly, I really want my $%&#ing book back.
title: A Death In Venice, And New York - missed connections

body: So here's the short story version of the chance encounter that this city is made for...Man 2 man, we met at that coffee shop on East 6th near 1st ave.  Yeah. Too bad you couldn't make it over then for more talk and that deep tissue rub down, a happy much needed release of yer stress and duress.  Hope your exams and oral reports went well.  So, remember, I'm not too far from you in East Village near St. Marks Church.  If your schedule's free now or soon then come on over and I'll give you an easy exam, oral only, no paper or cyber w/grades and such, only inquistive, probing and learning from the inquiries, and you'll report, give feedback, a learning experience for us both, man to man, older-younger, a great combo for such.  Very Greek, ancient, pre-Socratic, the dialectical procedure of evocation via inquiry and patient demonstration.  Hands on learning.  Experiential.  Best way to learn. I recall you're Asian - Korean perhaps? 3rd culture? didn't ask, doesn't matter, whatever, very nice looks, and masculine, good shape...hard to tell what age you are, what, 18 to 28? anyway, you're med study intensities then needed (still need) some hands on contact.  That's pretty much it.  Just in case you forgot, I'm the older man with the psychology books, the ones on dreams and their interpretation  - you shared a few dreams, the one with the airborn wheelbarrow and the fox, wow, much to say about that one - stacked high on the table lol, almond croissant crumbs on said books, table top, my lap,  powdered sugar on my chin and black shirt, yikes, thanx for pointing that out! lol.  Oy! First impressions!!!  You sat at the table next to me at Elsewhere and asked about the books, what I do - teach, write, consult/counsel, also massage and energy work so I too can change channels out of my head and into more physical relating to life, self, others, etc.  You said your brain was 'maxed out', you were extremely anxious and hadn't slept but a few hours a night for weeks and that your 'body needed to come alive.' After some rest and relaxation, some natural easy release of all that stress, your nervous system is maxed out, neurochemicals of cortisol storms depleted your adrenals, glands, and the subjective experience of who you are as a body whose ego is afflicted with academic demands for high achievement. Jeez.  I'm exhausted just describing you to yourself!  So.  'Yeah.  I'm perfect for that,' I said.  You grinned wide.  'Deal?' 'Deal!'  High fives and a wink wink to seal it.  And I bought your macha and your gluten free cookie for you.  What's a gentleman to do after all, the surprise of a friendly meeting, great conversation and sharing, laughing (as quietly as possible in that tiny espresso joint, tables close beside each other).  Yes, I do look younger for my age,  wear it, age, well, I work out at a gym not too far from you.  I'm toned.  Said I wasn't into that body building stuff...just tone, keep it together, get some cardio since I sit alot, am stationary too much because a lot of my work is studying, reading, writing so, yeah, I need to move it and shake loose.  About me, we didn't get into this when we met, Spanish mixed background, mom Cherokee Indian and Irish mix, dad Canary Islander (Spain), Latino, stray gringo in there too, southern Louisiana swamp dna mix, I guess, beast of the southern wild meets my dinner with Andre (an ancient movie, check it out), ...my green eyes come from mom tho.  She and dad grayed early.  Both wore it well as do I.  Laughter is indeed the best medicine and regular body contact and frequent rest.  Getting some of whatever off the chest too.  Soft belly breaths and deep sighs, hands soft on sky parts skin and and rough patches too to undo daily grind in exchange for bump kind, grind that is.  Skies and sighs the limit.  And deep let go.  Hasten slowly, said one of my best teachers in massage and trance work.  Yes.  That.  Exactly.  So if by chance you see this get in touch.  Summer's here.  I have time on my hands too and so can get my hands to work on you if yer up for it, all of it, handfuls of ahhhhhh soooooooooo.....and steady as he goes.  You'll be in control at all times.  I do only what you are comfortable with, respect boundaries.  You said you are shy so I want to remind you what I said about discretion and boundaries and that 'you da boss' - you call the shots, I swallow them or something like that lol.  We can go into all that and more when you contact me.And, yes, I will read you some Walt Whitman, the Calamus poems, a few of his entries from Specimen  Days, those tender civil war accounts of his sweet presence with the wounded soldiers, north and south, white and black...but that's enough.  And after the body work and rest/relax/deep snooze.Am up late too. Summer hours for lingering.  Soon then, I hope.

body: So here's the short story version of the chance encounter that this city is made for...I'm talkin about real people meeting up, NOT adolescent porn driven fantasies which are auto-erotic and actually get in the way of actual real people and their bodies/selves meeting...so please, no Peter Pans, hairy ones especially, those Eternal Boiz who live in their heads sexually and who insist that their fantasy porn-driven images/fantasises show up for them to have auto-erotic (extremely narcissistic) non-encounters but with what is in their 15 year old heads...that is SOOOO loathsome and a nuclear turn-off:Man 2 man, we met at that coffee shop on East 6th near 1st ave.  Yeah. Too bad you couldn't make it over then for more talk and that deep tissue rub down, a happy much needed release of yer stress and duress.  Hope your exams and oral reports went well.  So, remember, I'm not too far from you in East Village near St. Marks Church.  If your schedule's free now or soon then come on over and I'll give you an easy exam, oral only, no paper or cyber w/grades and such, only inquistive, probing and learning from the inquiries, and you'll report, give feedback, a learning experience for us both, man to man, older-younger, a great combo for such.  Very Greek, ancient, pre-Socratic, the dialectical procedure of evocation via inquiry and patient demonstration.  Hands on learning.  Experiential.  Best way to learn. I recall you're Asian - Korean perhaps? 3rd culture? didn't ask, doesn't matter, whatever, very nice looks, and masculine, good shape...hard to tell what age you are, what, 18 to 28? anyway, you're med study intensities then needed (still need) some hands on contact.  That's pretty much it.  Just in case you forgot, I'm the older man with the psychology books, the ones on dreams and their interpretation  - you shared a few dreams, the one with the airborn wheelbarrow and the fox, wow, much to say about that one - stacked high on the table lol, almond croissant crumbs on said books, table top, my lap,  powdered sugar on my chin and black shirt, yikes, thanx for pointing that out! lol.  Oy! First impressions!!!  You sat at the table next to me at Elsewhere and asked about the books, what I do - teach, write, consult/counsel, also massage and energy work so I too can change channels out of my head and into more physical relating to life, self, others, etc.  You said your brain was 'maxed out', you were extremely anxious and hadn't slept but a few hours a night for weeks and that your 'body needed to come alive.' After some rest and relaxation, some natural easy release of all that stress, your nervous system is maxed out, neurochemicals of cortisol storms depleted your adrenals, glands, and the subjective experience of who you are as a body whose ego is afflicted with academic demands for high achievement. Jeez.  I'm exhausted just describing you to yourself!  So.  'Yeah.  I'm perfect for that,' I said.  You grinned wide.  'Deal?' 'Deal!'  High fives and a wink wink to seal it.  And I bought your macha and your gluten free cookie for you.  What's a gentleman to do after all, the surprise of a friendly meeting, great conversation and sharing, laughing (as quietly as possible in that tiny espresso joint, tables close beside each other).  Yes, I do look younger for my age,  wear it, age, well, I work out at a gym not too far from you.  I'm toned.  Said I wasn't into that body building stuff...just tone, keep it together, get some cardio since I sit alot, am stationary too much because a lot of my work is studying, reading, writing so, yeah, I need to move it and shake loose.  About me, we didn't get into this when we met, Spanish mixed background, mom Cherokee Indian and Irish mix, dad Canary Islander (Spain), Latino, stray gringo in there too, southern Louisiana swamp dna mix, I guess, beast of the southern wild meets my dinner with Andre (an ancient movie, check it out), ...my green eyes come from mom tho.  She and dad grayed early.  Both wore it well as do I.  Laughter is indeed the best medicine and regular body contact and frequent rest.  Getting some of whatever off the chest too.  Soft belly breaths and deep sighs, hands soft on sky parts skin and and rough patches too to undo daily grind in exchange for bump kind, grind that is.  Skies and sighs the limit.  And deep let go.  Hasten slowly, said one of my best teachers in massage and trance work.  Yes.  That.  Exactly.  So if by chance you see this get in touch.  Summer's here.  I have time on my hands too and so can get my hands to work on you if yer up for it, all of it, handfuls of ahhhhhh soooooooooo.....and steady as he goes.  You'll be in control at all times.  I do only what you are comfortable with, respect boundaries.  You said you are shy so I want to remind you what I said about discretion and boundaries and that 'you da boss' - you call the shots, I swallow them or something like that lol.  We can go into all that and more when you contact me.And, yes, I will read you some Walt Whitman, the Calamus poems, a few of his entries from Specimen  Days, those tender civil war accounts of his sweet presence with the wounded soldiers, north and south, white and black...but that's enough. You were buying a drink for your boss across the street at the GNC. You immediately smiled when you saw me and I knew immediately who you were. You grew up to be such a handsome guy. We chatted a little, but you had to go. I think you came back a few times after that day. But one day I got the courage to go find you at your job. But alas I couldn’t find you and that was that. body: So here's the short story version of the chance encounter that this city is made for...Man 2 man, we met at that coffee shop on East 6th near 1st ave.  Yeah. Too bad you couldn't make it over then for more talk and that deep tissue rub down, a happy much needed release of yer stress and duress.  Hope your exams and oral reports went well.  So, remember, I'm not too far from you in East Village near St. Marks Church.  If your schedule's free now or soon then come on over and I'll give you an easy exam, oral only, no paper or cyber w/grades and such, only inquistive, probing and learning from the inquiries, and you'll report, give feedback, a learning experience for us both, man to man, older-younger, a great combo for such.  Very Greek, ancient, pre-Socratic, the dialectical procedure of evocation via inquiry and patient demonstration.  Hands on learning.  Experiential.  Best way to learn. I recall you're Asian - Korean perhaps? 3rd culture? didn't ask, doesn't matter, whatever, very nice looks, and masculine, good shape...hard to tell what age you are, what, 18 to 28? anyway, you're med study intensities then needed (still need) some hands on contact.  That's pretty much it.  Just in case you forgot, I'm the older man with the psychology books, the ones on dreams and their interpretation  - you shared a few dreams, the one with the airborn wheelbarrow and the fox, wow, much to say about that one - stacked high on the table lol, almond croissant crumbs on said books, table top, my lap,  powdered sugar on my chin and black shirt, yikes, thanx for pointing that out! lol.  Oy! First impressions!!!  You sat at the table next to me at Elsewhere and asked about the books, what I do - teach, write, consult/counsel, also massage and energy work so I too can change channels out of my head and into more physical relating to life, self, others, etc.  You said your brain was 'maxed out', you were extremely anxious and hadn't slept but a few hours a night for weeks and that your 'body needed to come alive.' After some rest and relaxation, some natural easy release of all that stress, your nervous system is maxed out, neurochemicals of cortisol storms depleted your adrenals, glands, and the subjective experience of who you are as a body whose ego is afflicted with academic demands for high achievement. Jeez.  I'm exhausted just describing you to yourself!  So.  'Yeah.  I'm perfect for that,' I said.  You grinned wide.  'Deal?' 'Deal!'  High fives and a wink wink to seal it.  And I bought your macha and your gluten free cookie for you.  What's a gentleman to do after all, the surprise of a friendly meeting, great conversation and sharing, laughing (as quietly as possible in that tiny espresso joint, tables close beside each other).  Yes, I do look younger for my age,  wear it, age, well, I work out at a gym not too far from you.  I'm toned.  Said I wasn't into that body building stuff...just tone, keep it together, get some cardio since I sit alot, am stationary too much because a lot of my work is studying, reading, writing so, yeah, I need to move it and shake loose.  About me, we didn't get into this when we met, Spanish mixed background, mom Cherokee Indian and Irish mix, dad Canary Islander (Spain), Latino, stray gringo in there too, southern Louisiana swamp dna mix, I guess, beast of the southern wild meets my dinner with Andre (an ancient movie, check it out), ...my green eyes come from mom tho.  She and dad grayed early.  Both wore it well as do I.  Laughter is indeed the best medicine and regular body contact and frequent rest.  Getting some of whatever off the chest too.  Soft belly breaths and deep sighs, hands soft on sky parts skin and and rough patches too to undo daily grind in exchange for bump kind, grind that is.  Skies and sighs the limit.  And deep let go.  Hasten slowly, said one of my best teachers in massage and trance work.  Yes.  That.  Exactly.  So if by chance you see this get in touch.  Summer's here.  I have time on my hands too and so can get my hands to work on you if yer up for it, all of it, handfuls of ahhhhhh soooooooooo.....and steady as he goes.  You'll be in control at all times.  I do only what you are comfortable with, respect boundaries.  You said you are shy so I want to remind you what I said about discretion and boundaries and that 'you da boss' - you call the shots, I swallow them or something like that lol.  We can go into all that and more when you contact me.And, yes, I will read you some Walt Whitman, the Calamus poems, a few of his entries from Specimen  Days, those tender civil war accounts of his sweet presence with the wounded soldiers, north and south, white and black...but that's enough.  And after the body work and rest/relax/deep snooze.Am up late too. Summer hours for lingering.  Soon then, I hope. OH.  I'll need a photograph of you when you respond to this.  Thanx!
title: AznGuyNearNYU-UneededMassageNMoreButUhad2study - missed connections

body: Normally I wouldn't take to Missed Connections to find a woman whose beauty I admired. We all see beautiful people every day, and while moments like that are not trivial, they hardly deserve a post to Craigslist. But this was different. I was shopping at Whole Foods yesterday, and as I was contemplating the differences between Soy Sauce and Tamari, I caught a glimpse of a gorgeous woman passing by my aisle. It was so quick and in my periphery, but something told me I needed to follow-up. In that moment, I put the Organic, low-sodium Tamari back on the shelf and followed the general direction of this mirage. I passed by two aisles in Slo-Mo before I saw this woman inspecting yogurts in Dairy. I let out a gasp. An elderly woman sampling Veggie Chips from a bin looked up and said, 'Excuse me, did you say something?' I shook my head. Those chips looked nasty. I am not a man who ogles or objectifies women, but I'm not blind, and I certainly could not ignore the rush of endorphins and the elevated heart-rate that accompanied this singular moment in the Dairy aisle. I walked towards the Greek Yogurts, and with every step, my temperature rose. The woman I saw had brown, wavy hair with red highlights that fell a few inches past her shoulders. She is possibly 5'8' or 5'9'. She was wearing black Lululemon leggings and a fitted athletic top. From the profile, I could tell that her lips are full and soft. As I approached, I looked toward the shelf and grabbed a large tub of Vanilla Brown Cow Whole Milk yogurt. I looked at it, then I looked briefly at her. Our eyes met for the briefest of moments. Her eyes are blue and gorgeous. She gave me a brief smile, then looked away. I wanted to say something, anything. I wanted to tell her how breathtaking she is, but I didn't want to come off as creepy; I wanted to tell her that my body was reacting to her in ways it is not accustomed, but that would be psychotic; I wanted to ask her if she had ever tried Brown Cow yogurt, but maybe she would just judge me for the high fat content. I said nothing. And then, in an instant, she looked up one more time, smiled, and walked away. Now that moment is gone. It's over. And I cannot stop thinking about my Missed Connection. Is it possible that this such a perfect vision of a human being could be looking for me on this site? I have no idea. What I do know is that I bought Brown Cow yogurt but forgot the damn Tamari!
title: Friday at Whole Foods M4F - missed connections

body: Hey so I wasn't going to write at all because truthfully I was still pissed as F that you were gone after I had arrived back to El Burro.  I saw your post on here late yesterday afternoon on here after a friend pointed it out to me and although he suggested I write you back, I told my friend No Way, Jose.  Yo tengo problemo. Hmm looks like I took Spanish in high school too... Guess you're not the only one, eh?And since you mentioned my red shirt, which all of my friends know I have, the things I shared with you could now known by everyone.  Not cool but whatever.  And just to verify that it is me, you had on a black tank, flip flops, and jeans.  Your name started with a K and the second letter was an R but I don't want to write the whole thing on here because I believe in privacy unlike you, obviously.I don't know where I went wrong...  We super connected on the back patio and what we felt was real.  I'll admit that I was touched to see that you were able to recall a lot of conversation as evidence of what you posted on here.  While I was mad, that did make me feel better.  Still, ultimately I figured that you had left and met someone else then fell in love with them.When I arrived back to El Burro in a button down and blue jeans looking for you after I dumped out to pick up where we left off, I walked throughout the entire restaurant and calling out for your name. After about 30 minutes, a few patrons got annoyed and one even called me out.'A yo holmes, I don't think she here bro,' a guy told me as I stood on a chair in the back and scouted for you.  'I mean, you have been looking but umm you know, it doesn't look like she here mane.''That's impossible,' I replied.  'Furthermore if you disrespect my girlfriend's honor again, I will wreck you.  You and your friend.  Don't make that mistake again,' I warned him.I loved you and felt it was important to protect you.I wasn't going to allow anyone to say anything negative about you.  As far as I was concerned, we were a team.Anyways after those guys finally ceded trading turns beating me down with their respective pool sticks in the back parking lot about 20 minutes later, they finally returned my clothes and told me there were no hard feelings.  I rolled over on my back in pain and looked up at the same stars that you and I had seen earlier when we were talking.  I saw the big dipper and thought of your buttermilk tiddays and concluded immediately that if I had not gone home to shower and empty my gut, surely the undeserved beat down I had just received would have prompted it to leave my body there and then.  I managed to put on my pants and sat up as I tried to orient myself on the black asphalt.  I really wanted to retaliate on my beat down so I went up to a pole in the parking lot that housed a handicap sign and used my strength to move it back and forth and extract it from the ground while making a series of grunts.'COME ON YOU SON OF A BITCH,' I said to encourage my efforts.  I did this for awhile until realizing that it wasn't going to come out of the ground and that it was in there pretty good.  So I moved over to another one that looked more promising and tried it with that one instead...'COME ON YOU SON OF A BITCH,' I grunted once again.  But sure enough, that one wasn't budging either.  I should also mention that while my pants were on, I had tied my button down around my head like a bandanna and smeared some black asphalt on my face so that I would look more intimidating walking back up to the two men who gave me a beat down to retaliate accordingly.  Dehydrated and still a little emotional from being hit by the pool sticks repeatedly, I began talking to myself as I searched that parking lot for something I could make into a weapon.  'Oooo now you gonna get it!  Here I come!  You can't stop me, naw uh, no way baby.  What am I gone do?  I'm gone get him back, that what!'Luckily, I spotted a mop handle sans mop head resting against the back wall of the building.  I grabbed it and did a few practice spins to get my technique right.  I wasn't satisfied with my results so I began to sharpen it on the ground by rubbing the tip at an angle.  I had revised my approach of using it as a bow staff and instead planned on using as a large shiv after screaming and running towards the primary wrongdoer soon after locating them.  With the other guy, now that I would be weaponless, I was going to kick him with my dominate leg and watch his body bust through the wall on the other side.  Almost ready, I began a series of heavy pants in the parking lot to work up my energy and exact my revenge (while holding the bowstaff-dagger in a series of holds in case they were watching).It was during this time I was tazzered by a responding unit who had been called after people saw the pool stick beat down.'That's it rookie, hold the trigger down on the tazzer for about 30 seconds or until the device in your hand starts becoming hot.  You're doing great,' the senior officer told his trainee as I flopped around on the ground.'The device is hot but he hasn't defecated himself yet, should I keep going?'  The rookie responded.  'You said they should defecate too when we were back in the car.''I told you they usually defecate, very good.  But this guy is clearly on opiods and is probably malnourished.  Give him around 5 more minutes of volt juice and if he hasn't messed up his pants we will arrest him and  AND...?''....umm file the report?''...No, that's when we get back to the station.  What do we do AFTER we cuff him? ...We...''...Oh!   We send a snapchat to other units in our group chat!' The rookie said with confidence.'ANDDDDD I think you are finally a cop rookie!  NICE!  Here, we wiill use my phone this time, I could use the points.'This was the last thing I could remember.So pardon me if I don't want to write you back directly.  I am still recovering and need some time and I am just not sure I can bring myself to trust you.I haven't ruled it out completely bur right now I am still skeptical if seeing you again is a good idea.- Guy in the Red Shirt

body: I had a very visceral reaction to all the bar-hopping kids under my window, shouting at each other to wait up and finishing sentences begun earlier on crowded, tile floors. Beyond the usual, 'shut up, I'm trying to sleep.' A purer venom, burning clean, high octane. Violent, rooted, won't back down-kind of intolerance. Reminding myself that I was young once, not too long ago. Like them. Running along just behind the pack, walking with you. No specific plans. No need. The rustle of leaves in autumn weather like this, when the winds from Canada just keep flowing down from the unseen north. When you stand on a corner at midnight and know that summer has gone for good and yes, winter is coming. There would be no point in looking at your picture. Nostalgia is a toxin. But there is some salve in revisiting the images in my mind: your hand in mine, the look on your face as you skip from the cab to the curb to greet me. Autumn sun on the Upper East Side. Towering buildings watching silently. A world out there, ahead. Your smile the focus of a million tiny thoughts.

I committed a crime 4/5 years ago and because of that, I have a criminal history. I do not deny what I’ve done, and do not make excuses as to why I did it. Any reason I give, would be an excuse to me and there is none. So I never answer that question when I am asked why. As you can imagine, having a criminal history makes it hard for me to find a good job. I am not lazy. I love to work. I love to help people. I take whatever job I can get, but I need a better stable job. I was hoping that someone who is in the position to hire or refer me to someone that is hiring for an office job or any job that can help me SURVIVE would read this. body: Hey guys, below I'm sharing a little about myself, my interest, likes etc. What has changed would be my daily routine do to the 'Covid-19'....absolutely horrible...…, but still always up for making a new aquaintence and or friend.Well i'm not going to mention my ethnicity, racial backround.......could be black, white, hispanic, asian or perhaps a proud mutt!.......if that really matters to you, then please don't read any further.....though i'm 45yrs, 6', good shape (not a gym rat). At the moment i'll just say i'm a gay male who's straight friendly.......lol....Here's my story:It's rather unfortunate I don't come from a closely nit family like many of you guys do (smiles)....though I do love my immediate family despite their selfish habits! Can get abit lonely at times....especially around the holidays....though I do have my artificial tree that sets in a stand that rotates the tree dressed with ornaments from friends/aquaintences unfortunately 'not local', but from around the world! It's what gets me through ChristmasI call it my 'friendship' tree and of course talking with relatives/friends that reside in other countries instead of family living only 30 minutes away:(...Don't feel sad for me, feel glad that i'm alive and well......and able to share this with you (smiles).I was recently asked about a 'beneficiary' and I had to really think about that. I couldn't put a name down...at least anyone that lives near by!......I was also asked 'who can I completely trust that lives near by......I drew a blank!..........pretty sad huh!? So now the warmer weather is upon us.....i'm setting out to make that 'blank space' no more.Little about me:I'm a very happy, go lucky kinda guy who tries to enjoy life to the best of my ability. I consider myself: humorous, honest, loving, generous (just stay away from my money.....lol.....kidding not that I have a lot cause I don't..) very personable, passionate, smart and lots of street smarts as well....topped of with lots of integrity!I can spend hours roaming 'Michaels & AC Moore' letting my imagination run wild. Can spend time roaming the halls of the Culinary Institute as a proud Gourmand! Can walk the isles of Gander Mountain sifting through all the camping, outdoor gear! Can toss a cake or turkey into an oven....then toss a football yards away! Hang out at Homo Depot...(joking had to throw that in there...lol...).....Stroll the Dia museum..... Can adapt to most any enviornment....be it weather to people! Enjoy some sports, the arts, the bright lights and soaking up all that positive energy that NYC can thrust at me;)....looking to learn how to ride a motorcycle for the spring....so guy(s) hope to hear from someone(s). Update (9/8/19) I live in Orange Cnty NY and I absolutely love NYC and love spending weekends in NYC....be it broadway, movies, strolling Manhattan, dining at dessert café or a descent steakhouse (a true gourmand here). I am up for almost anything. Perhaps starting out with a friendly email or text can jump start a new friendship! I got my motorcycle license about 3 yrs ago (I am still pretty much a beginner, but getting better.) During the fall i'm thinking about renting a motorcycle just for starters. I once in a while drive, but mostly take the train into NYC often, but I do live about 1hr northwest up in the Hudson Valley. MetroNorth has a great ride along the Hudson river to Beacon Train Station as well......So if u wanna get out of NYC you'd be more the welcome to come on up and visit (get out of NYC for a change).....for me distance for a potentially good friend is no big deal. Hope to hear from someone.Love meeting people from all over!So if your really, really, really serious and would entertain making a new friend, here I am!Thanx for taking the time to read my post. One last thing, I've come across many people, straight, gay, different races and monetary statuses....just remember this; relationships be it acquaintances, friendships, marriages....they all require hard work of compromise, understanding, an open mind/heart, acceptance and integrity.....if you have these qualities in your soul, then you have a great recipe for attaining happiness.....just finding that last ingredient of that good friend:)) takes time, but we all have a good recipe somewhere.Again I certainly don't want to waste your time, so if race, creed, color, monetary status really matters to you, then I don't think even an acquaintance would develop. Thanx again guys (smiles)
