body: Our missed connection took place yesterday (Monday) in the early morning.I’d prefer not to say which store this occurred, especially if I am so lucky to have you find this post and write me back.  So for that purpose I’ll refer to it so Ferizon in this report.  It was a bit chilly out, with that weird sort of energy still in the air from everyone being quarantined.I happened to be off from work, so I decided to head to Ferizon and see about upgrading my phone since my screen was cracked and because I have had it for a long time.  After grabbing coffee, I parked and walked a short distance to to try and be one of the first in after they were set to open.  My to do list for the day was moderately long but I had a positive energy in my walk as I was getting an early head start on my agenda.  Walking with a smile and an upbeat stride, I meandered around the corner and saw you, and only you, pacing back and forth while sucking down on a cigarette.  Abiding by the distancing stuff, I stood back a good distance and kept to myself.  Personally I wasn’t sure you even noticed me or that you were one for small talk.  But in fact you spoke to me right away and as it so happens I am attracted to that level of confidence.‘They think they can screw me, that they can just jack up my bill for no reason, and that I won’t do actually won’t do anything about it?  Biggest mistake they will ever make,’ you said to me to break the ice.  ‘They probably thought I’d just stay home and not do anything about it and for that reason they severely miscalculated.’‘I’m sorry, what happened exactly?  I don’t think I heard y-’‘OHHH don’t even get me started.  This goes back several years and let me assure you and anyone else listening that I WILL COME OUT WINNING.  These savages tripled my bill last month and said I didn’t really have an unlimited plan.  BULLSHIT.  Nobody screws me over like this, I got papers and documents to prove it, right here.’I didn’t want to rile you up any further, I didn’t think you needed the encouragement either.  But admittedly, I can attest the Ferizon has tried to F me in the B several times, whether it was by saying my unlimited plan had a limit, or by adding items onto my bill that I never authorized.‘Good for you for being organized.  I hope they do the right thing,’ I said to you.‘They have no choice but to do the right thing.  And just between me and you, one doesn’t play metal gear solid for 6 months and not learn a thing or too.  I promise that on the souls of my dea-’‘Hey you guys can come in, we are open now,’ the manager interjected.  ‘It’s just me here for the first hour so I will help him first and then you, cool?’  I nodded in the affirmative as the both of us stepped inside.  Immediately, you started laying your case as you and the manger stationed yourselves by a standing desk.  I had no choice but to eavesdrop since it was so quiet inside.  You were being very colorful in your argument and made a compelling case.  Moreover, while I was really crossing my fingers that Ferizon would do the right thing, my logical side knew there was no hope.  After the manager looked at his computer screen for several minutes and made a quick phone call of some sort, he walked back towards you to pass down his verdict as you stood there with your arms crossed.‘Ok, so I just talked to my supervisor.  And it does look like you had an unlimited plan.  However, it was cancelled by us because you used too much data.  There is nothing I can do but before you snap, please know that I truly hate working here, for real.  I know you want to punch me in the face but I’m just here because I need a job.  I hate these guys just as much as you do, no joke,’ he offered in an effort to quell your anger.‘So that’s it?  You just switched my plan on me and now I owe you an amount that’s almost equal to one month’s rent?  And you think, you really think that there won’t be any repercussions?’‘Societal repercussions don’t exist in America anymore unless you say something mean about someone who is transgender.  If it’s about the banks or whatever, studies show you’re just gonna go home and drink.  I took an online webinar on this just last week.  The truth is, I could double your bill right now and there is still only a 5% chance you’ll even switch providers.’You stood there silent at a loss of words.  I too heard what he said and had difficulty doubting what he was saying.  Now it was your move.  He had used his word jazz and created a great posture of defense while disabling your reaction to Ferizon’s inaction.  What were you going to do?  I had no idea.  But the overall tension of watching this unfold made really feel like getting my butthole licked from behind for some reason.‘My friend, you just made a BIG mistake.  I came here to offer you stupid bitches an olive branch, not thinking you would be stupid enough not to take it.  So you’re not gonna reimburse me, ok, cool.  I asked and you said no because you are a corporate cuck, I get it.  If you excuse me, I am going to leave now,’ you said while placing some sunglasses on your face and heading to the door.  Before you stepped out, you turned around to deliver one last comment.  ‘Oh one last thing.’‘What’s that?’ The manager asked.‘Enjoy this  ...power... of yours while it lasts,’ you said before you hastily walked out.Whether it was my instinct or my ovaries, I reflexively followed you out of the store, having no idea what you were up to.  I hurried around the building to find you with no exact plan in mind whereupon I located you in the back of the building.  In a very cool way, you had cut open the electrical box, not even the slightest disturbed by my presence.‘Don’t try to talk me out of this, it has to be done,’ you said as you opened the box.With a newly lit cigarette in your mouth, you then took your dong (decently sized) out of your zipper hole and peed all on the wires and sockets inside as it began to spark and emit smoke while make a buzzing sound.  I could tell the building had already lost power.  What confused me was that it seemed risky for you to do this, not judicially, but physically since electricity is apolitical.  ‘HEY ARENT YOU AFRAID OF GETTING ELECTROCUTED BY DOIN THIS?’ I asked over the increasing sounds of the electrical boxes buzzing.‘NOT A CHANCE, THE MOST ILL GET IS 3 MONTHS AND MAYBE OH WAIT DID YOU MEAN-’ And just as it dawned on you that your plan was not thought well through, surely enough a bolt of electricity arrived through your pee and sent your body up in the air and back until you were stopped by the brick wall of the adjacent building.  I could tell power had gone out in the area as I walked up to assess you.  You were laying on your side and out of it, with your dong still out.  Interestingly, it had darkened and was bigger in size due to the swelling and even though I should have been running away, the sight of it wanted me to get pregnant in the mouth.‘Hey are you ok??’Unfortunately you were confused and saying weird things back to me.  ‘Cell phone pee, for there.  I go up, but here in the pee and now the wall and the box.’‘Say that again?’‘I got the box, for my cell, now the pee got me.  The pee it boom, cause box.’After you turned over I saw you had shit your pants so I tuned around want went home.Now I can’t stop thinking about your dong.  So I’m writing this to say I’m sorry I left you and that I hope you are ok.Are you?  Want some soup?

body: You knew I used to love reading these, and I subtly wrote you many throughout the years. I don't believe you've thought of me enough to ever check... or maybe its a pain to find my sporadic sentiments amidst lewd confessions of the underbelly. But let it be known to the world if not to you. For me that will do.It's strange. I think I'm in your shoes now... where I'm the love of someone's life but they aren't mine. Part of me doesn't want to believe that nature can be that cruel. I think that fate ought to save us so long as we are willing to listen... and move according to our true feelings. So that's what I'm trying to do.I can never seem to tell if you cared too much or not at all. It's more palatable to take it as too much, to mark what you did as an act of vengeance and not callousness. But perhaps that is wishful thinking. I can recognize that now.... but I don't believe for a second it was all an illusion. I know you loved me, even if cruelty simultaneously existed inside you. The same is true within me... and strangely.... that is part of why I love you.But I fed the wolf that is constructive. I tried to be good. I try to be better. I am as much as I can be. Its the only way to find self-solace... to constrain the monster... to turn the destroyer into a creator. Without the self righteousness associated with this verb I'm about to use, and in complete earnest, I pray that you realize the same. I can't stand to know you're in pain, but as much as I want to, it can't be me to take it away.I can't ever stop thinking about you... the way your face changed...I wonder if everyone else can see it too.... if it's as jarring... as obvious to them what wolf you fed...Just like it wasn't you who really broke me, I know it wasn't me who broke you. But we were each other's final blow... what finally made the other fold, having been stepped on all those years before. And for that I am both sorry and grateful.I know now we need to be on our own.But don't think for a damn minute that I don't love you. That I've ever stopped. That the time has made me forget what I cannot recall but know existed.It's a shame visceral feelings cannot survive in thought.But I have the writings. I have the pain. The loss. The pining.And admittedly, you are a far better muse than you were a lover then. But I loved you. I still love you anyway. Since I saw you through the rectangle and always.I have faith in some distant someday.But hurry up would you? It would be a hell of a lot more practical than a middle aged tryst and all the paperwork of two divorces. Jesus.
title: N. Bupkins - missed connections

body: Mom talks about the sister of a celebrity she once knew overdosing during highschool. That was then, though, and this is now. On the plane, Homer Simpson stops a missile for his deceased hippie mom; her foible of political protest living on from beyond the grave. Walking the aisles, elderly women play solitaire, while self-important men watch the business news on a too-tiny tv, schlepping their wives’ bags but taking a reprieve to sit with the market. Adjacent to the bathroom, a venerable rabbi types out a sermon via I-pad, something about sacrifice. Mom doesn’t remember what she overdosed on.The passage of time speaks through a woman’s heavily accented English, announcing that she sleeps through the day because soon she won’t be able to. My grandfather got up at five in the morning, Saturdays too, until he was seventy-six. When you get to be a certain age all you want is a good meal. Years and relationships collapse into moments, realizations of fraught situations. Everytime I walk into their garage, there are piles of Dr. Brown’s cream sodas, seemingly untouched when we don’t visit. The day ends. When she talks about being better off dead he squeezes her hand.Dinner gets filled with displaced memories. Every Irish-Catholic they grew up with is a cop or a criminal, and one is usually cousins with the other. My cousin talks about his relation to all of the people he works with at a corporate park off the New Jersey turnpike. He didn’t know they were related until he ran into one at a funeral. Hoboken is about a mile from top to bottom; my uncle talks about growing up there, the state of things. Most of his cousins were racist or penniless, but one of them helped lead the Latin Kings.We never know which of the little girls is her, in all their blonde and juvenile appearances. Still, the photos muster the appearance of appearances; they flatten, put distance between a past that becomes more romantic the longer you look at the print fade. There are photos of a man standing on a lion that he’s killed, and the longer I look at it the more I forget I’m related to him. Nothing’s what it used to be. Everything rhymes with what used to be. You look like your father’s son. My grandmother is the small one on the right.

body: When I step outside my house, I remember the apocalypse never arrives. Trees stand in rows, positively idyllic; my dog stops at every new stretch of grass for the chance to stop and lick the wind. Sometimes it strikes me that everything is feeling. How cruel that even that becomes a structure. I go to the park too, where I remember sociality in every beaming and wretched instance. There are little wooden pegs around the playgrounds but the sounds linger over them. Again: imprints. You’ll come to understand.In my dream there was a gameshow. You were one of the contestants, but the details are lost on me now. It seemed related to ritual in some way, but then again, maybe most things do. Does this one have a wheel, or does the mind matter? Games are always at hand anyway, isn’t that the matrix of competition? Perhaps it’s all a matter of degrees: forgive us lord, for we know not what we do. In another one, there’s an airport, wandering from plastics to steel. Different connections.Some days my brain works, others it fails in embarrassing turns. The biggest fear is the brain failing in some more official and lasting way. What then? Affect and viscerality will remain but none of the things that make them potent. Memory would become like the tadpoles swimming up a stream that you cup in your hand. A moment, then they slip through the cracks. I keep thinking about the summer of 2016, and wondering if there might be anyway to understand what it means to you now. Attics, woods with shattered bottles, desperate transfers in Secaucus. Is there anyway that any of it can be brought to mean, to cohere? Appearance says you mature, while I sense in myself only sublimation. But appearance is surface, even in finality.None of us knew how to drive cars. I could barely contain the anxious expressions of my consciousness, or my independence. I’m much the same today but nobody believes it. Everything opens up to some degree, but I usually sense the narrow element, fixity without closure. I stare at my photographs, but they don’t capture or distill anything, only represent. I miss the lilting voices of Haitian grandmothers, the sights of men who shrink outwards playing bocce. Even the corporate parks feel a massive distance. I find new cuts and holes, and I burrow and mutate. Counting the specks on my carpet, alternate: yellow, black, tan, beige. Until tomorrow.

body: I've said it, as I'm sure you have in our hiatus. And I wanted to mean it, I wanted to feel it, so I said it in hopes perhaps I could manifest it's existence by breathing it back to men I pity almost as much as myself.And they were nice boys. Nicer than you. They bought me flowers and took me to meet their mothers. And I didn't hate it. Often times it was enjoyable.But it was fruitless. My wishful thinking again proved useless, and by that time the truth had become more palatable, and I more honorable. I told them that I had already given away what they sought... my heart and my hand to a man I could no longer bring myself to speak with.And I recall one at a restaurant who, well, actually wasn't so nice after all, but he was right when he told me it was the dumbest thing he ever heard... waiting for a man who wounded me years ago. And I laughed. I laughed at the absurdity of it, how much even my sizable ego was no match for the caliber of what I felt.You seemed to overpower just about everything about me. Even the radio silence couldn’t dim my feelings.And all of them longed for only an ounce of me, but I gave nothing away except the kindness I would a stranger. But my heart is bigger than most and I more generous to strangers so they never noticed.My agony they took as a restless demeanor, my craving for as much space as a marker of an independent woman.'You hate it when I touch you.' he mused. But he still did it anyway, I think in hopes my mind would succumb alongside the physical. It was never any good.The trouble was in being capable of loving so much, and being reduced to not being able to at all.And having to half ass it, trying to force it was excruciating. I thought perhaps I didn't like men to begin with, and sometimes so did they.But it was just you, wasn't it? The one my heart had never rid, making it impossible for me to ever fall in love again.I think we had it right the first time.

body: I blame it on the shut-down/quarantine.   Working from home, bored and a little stir crazy and still think of you.  It’s not unusual, just perhaps a bit more time to dwell on it.  It’s been 10 years (yikes).  We would leave notes for each other in missed connections. We actually met on craigs in what I believe we thought would be a harmless Sunday night chat – but it escalated quickly.  We were both in a rut of sorts.  Life was good and we had no intention of changing our situations, but had needs/desires and wanted to feel something.  It was passionate, intoxicating (and sometimes all-consuming), and we both knew it was temporary.  We were clear-eyed about what it was and what it could be, enjoyed our time together and managed to keep it all separate and a secret from our real lives.  All things come to an end, and real-life circumstances and requirements brought us to our senses.I still enjoy the memories…. Long relaxing conversations, shared music, exploring each other mentally and physically…. Simple lunches…. Juvenile-like meetings in parks and parking lots…. Seemed impossible to find then and now, and perhaps for the best.

Live with passion, and embrace the spirit of Seattle just steps away from the best concerts and festivals in the city. Hugging the cusp of Queen Anne and Belltown, you'll be a stone's throw away from historical restaurants, retail, museums, and parks. Find your passion, find your verve. Unique and Seattle-centric amenity spaces will give you options to play all year long. There’s even space for your furry best friend to chill out and enjoy the view in our community dog park. Find yourself at the center and call Verve home.
